item.description: The Drinking Roulette contains 16 glasses for vodka which have their place around the roulette. Some of the glasses should be filled with vodka, some with water. Players bet red or black and those players who bet correctly drink one glass of vodka or water (they don't know). If a player bet 0 and guess, he/she drinks all the glasses. After drinking each player is allowed to leave the game. The last player in the game is declared the winner.

Game of speed and observation.
Players draw cards in front of them and when two identical cards are stacked, the first player to cry as an animal of those cards wins all the cards drawn. There are rooster, duck, donkey, cow, pig, turkey etc. in this game. Last player in game is the winner.

name.value: Code Lyoko JCC: Attaque de X.A.N.A.

item.description:
Object of the game is to control the heros from the cartoon and help them to defeat XANA.

Each player uses up to five heroes who carry out specific actions and face certain dangers to score points. Victory points can also be earn by playing some cards.

The winner is the first player to reach 20 points.

Starter deck contains 165 card.
There are two starter decks available: "Alert on Lyoko" and "The secret is in danger"

There are 110 cards where the color names are written but not necessarily the color of the background of this card.
So if It is written the word "blue" in red, you will tend to read "red" and not "blue."

The object is to get rid of his card by matching one of his written word of the color with the color on card's background on the table. And the task is not so easy as you might think, since in addition, other players can be faster than you and change the game. Some wildcards are multicolored.

Players who gets rid of his cards first is the winner.

Matching game about colors and animals
In his turn player place a card in the middle of the table either with same animal or same color. Chameleons are like joker cards.

First player who gets rid of his cards first wins the game.

"All Animal Comrades believe that 1984 was a great year for the Animal Farm—at least, the Ministry of Truth claims so..."

1984: Animal Farm, a new game by the designers of Alcatraz: the Scapegoat, presents a dystopian reality in which animals have overthrown their human masters. When the fires of the revolution died down, a political game began to establish the only proper totalitarian regime. The players take the roles of animal dictators who will stop at nothing to gain absolute power over the global Farm.

1984: Animal Farm is a negotiation game for 3 to 5 players that's based on the concept of forced cooperation. On one hand, players share some business with their neighbors; on the other hand, they are divided by the will to win. The game favors efficient strategy, slick negotiations, and successful bluffing. At the same time, it forces the players to form temporary alliances with their enemies and keep an eye on their friends. All this makes each round of the game abound in heated talks (both public and secret), pacts, promises, and betrayals. Special abilities drawn before the game, along with the winning conditions, guarantee that no two games will be the same.

"Remember, fellow revolutionaries: All animals are equal, but some are more equal than others!"

item.description:
Game description from the publisher:

The year is 3012. It's been a millennium since the Armageddon. Deep in the Yucatan jungle, humanity has mutated, degenerated, and segregated into five clans: Jaguar, Snake, Monkey, Gar, and Bat. These clans now battle it out for dominance in the region, cooperating when it suits them and actively working against each other when the opportunity arises.

In 3012, players start the game with small decks of Scout cards, which provide gold to make purchases. Two piles of cards – an Ally deck and a Weapon deck – provide static cards to buy, with three cards from each deck always available to purchase each round. Cards that are not bought remain there for other players to buy. Two non-static Action decks – one with cheap cards, the other expensive – are also available, and at the start of your turn, you reveal one card from each of these two Action decks. You get the benefits of the Action cards you reveal, whether you buy them or not, and they're removed from play if you don't buy them.

When you have amassed enough combat skill through Allies, Weapons, and Action cards, you can attempt to prove your worth by facing a beast in four decks of Encounter cards, ranging from easy to very difficult.

Unlike most deck-building games, there are many points of interaction in 3012, so players are never out of the action! And you always get to refill your hand to its maximum size at the start of your turn, so you are never penalized for interacting during other players' turns.

The game ends when one of the Heroes reaches Level 5. The player with the most victory points wins the game.

item.description:
The 50's 
a game of your generation

This is a Monopoly clone from Late from the Sky, a publisher that specializes in themed Monopoly games. In The 50's game, Blocks of Time and Decades replace houses and hotels, Big Fun! and Contingency replace Chance and Community Chest cards, and all the properties and spaces on the board are 1950's themed. The tokens are a guitar, a 50's car, a jukebox, a male figure modeled on Elvis Presley, a shoe (blue suede?) and a pair of cat-eye glasses. As in all versions of monopoly, the last player left in the game wins.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Dungeon Command: Heart of Cormyr is a card-driven skirmish game played on modular interlocking map tiles that uses order cards, creature cards and miniatures. The object of the game is to have the highest remaining Morale when an opposing warband's Morale has been reduced to 0 or below, or if a player ends his or her turn with no creatures on the battlefield.

As a player, you take on the role of a commander, sending a warband to battle the forces arrayed against you. You recruit troops and deploy them on the battlefield. You issue orders to those creatures, outfit them with spells and equipment, and direct their tactics to break the morale of your enemies and drive them from the field.

Dungeon Command: Heart of Cormyr includes twelve miniatures, such as a ranger, a cleric, a knight, defenders, and archers. While each Dungeon Command faction is meant to be played by a single player, quick-start rules allow two players to engage in a shortened version of the game using only one box. Dungeon Command is designed for two players, although up to four can play with a few adjustments explained under the advanced rules.

Integrates with:

 Dungeon Command: Blood of Gruumsh
 Dungeon Command: Curse of Undeath
 Dungeon Command: Sting of Lolth
 Dungeon Command: Tyranny of Goblins




Can also integrate with:

 Dungeons & Dragons: Castle Ravenloft Board Game
 Dungeons & Dragons: The Legend of Drizzt Board Game
 Dungeons & Dragons: Wrath of Ashardalon Board Game
 Dungeons & Dragons: Temple of Elemental Evil Board Game

As a player, you take on the role of a commander, sending a warband to battle the forces arrayed against you. You recruit troops and deploy them on the battlefield. item.description:
42 cards represents one third of an animal: head, body or
legs - 14 animals in total.

In his turn player plays sets of animals with the symbol at the top of the card or invent imaginary creatures.

The winner is the one who put together the most animals.

Rules to the Dagobert Edition in French, English and German. Rules to the France Cartes edition in English, French and Spanish.

"In the near future players compete in a strategic boardgame called Cubotrix, a holographic table where a board is displayed and challenge peoples mind to overcame their oponent for the control of board´s areas"

A two player abstract game where players compete in a board made by dices in five different colors. The objective is to control moust of the board dices and create line patterns to score. The board chances every round, with new numbers coming up and others disapearing as the dice change position and faces. Each player needs to combine it´s own dices, hidden from the other player, and pair two numbers that match the same numbers on the board that are adjacent in order to ocupy both dices with one of it´s own control markers. Also players have a set of special actions they can perform once per game that bend the general rules of the game.

Game plays for 45 to 60 minutes.

"Deep in the Jungle the Ekebet, Mayan star messangers compete in the dangerous ritual race to bring glory to their city state. They must run day and night to reach the oposite city state before anyone else. With Kukulkan´s help, the great serpent god, they call for ancient power to reach victory".

An abstract game set in the Mayan culture for 2 to 4 players. Each player has a set of four runners that starts in their home city state and must run across to board, a jungle, to reach the oposite side, another city state. The player who reaches the oposite city state first with all his runners win the game. The pices movements are managed by a set of movement pieces. Each runner and each movement piece has two sides: day and night. When a runner moves, his piece change it´s side to a new status (day to night or night to day). Players need to manage their movement pieces in order to move their runners in the board according to their status each round. Some animals in the jungle block the runners path and each player can call for Kukulkan aid, special poker tokens that bend the general game rules.

Wong's Game is a 2 players abstract board game about stone placement and area influence invented by Gary Wong in 1999.

The game is played on an initial empty square board. Additionally each player should have a enough stones of their own color. Alternatively the author suggest that the game can be played with just paper and pencil.

The game is divided in a placement phase and a growing phase:


 Placement Phase - Each player, in turns, drops N-1 stones into empty cells (with a NxN board).



 Growing Phase - Each player continues to drop stones into empty cells, but now, each stone must have two or more adjacent friendly stones (by "adjacent" it should be understood "orthogonal or diagonal adjacent").


When both players are unable to move the one who has more stones in the board will be the winner.

item.description:
Abstract game of memory and pattern recognition. Players have two pieces in their hands and each round have to play one piece on the table, creating the board and buy a new piece to their hand.

Each piece is made of 3 connected hexagon, with different colors and shapes. To place pieces on the board, players need to connect at least 2 different hexagons matching or the colors or the numbers, or a mix of both from their hand to pieces already on the table.

Pieces can be placed adjacent to other pieces in the same level or placed over other pieces. Higher a piece is placed, more score a player gets.

Game ends when no more pieces can be added to the board and the player with higher score wins.

Legend: History of 1000 Miglia is the first title of a game series that will cover the history of the legendary car race across Italy from 1927 to 1955, starting from Brescia, then going to Rome and back. In particular, this first chapter covers the first years of the competition, between 1927 and 1933, when the biggest cars brands – Alfa Romeo, Lancia, Mercedes, etc. – struggle against all the odds in that tough race of 1000 miles (1000 Miglia, in Italian) in the worst conditions ever in the history of car racing and technology.

The 15 stages are realized by a combination of large hexagons, which represent the Italian countryside and its typical winding roads.

Particular attention was paid realizing a "playful simulation" in which all 19 cars featured in the game have their own characteristics, historically and technically recreated, after long research and interviews with the actual drivers of each car. So every car features its handling, engine performance and reliability with the goal of finding the right trade-off between simulation and entertainment.

The driver prepares his car to the race, acquiring spare parts and abilities that will help him along the way. He plans his speed for the turn and moves along the track dealing with different kind of curves, altitude gradients. He has to manage his car through 1000 miles of race, facing technical issues (14 different mechanical area of the car has been covered to model damage and mechanical wear!), changing weather conditions, daylight and nighttime, racing against the other drivers directly side-by-side and against their timing.

Who arrives back in Brescia with the fastest time wins the 1000 Miglia.

Previously known as 1000 Miglia: Dawn of the Myth.

item.description:
In the strategic tile-laying game Komodo, players are zoologists attempting to build new habitats for Australasian animals imperilled by an incoming asteroid. Each player holds two animal cards stating the type and amount of terrain needed, five multi-terrain tiles, and wild cards. On a turn, they may lay up to three tiles, place one or both of their animals in free-form contiguous blocks of appropriate terrain, and use all or some of their wild cards. The starter tile has two blocks of each of the four terrain types: forest, grassland, desert and water. The number of blocks of terrain needed by an animal is equivalent to the number of points you can score by placing it. When the tile supply is exhausted, each player takes a final turn, then loses points for any unplaced animals still in hand. The player with the highest score wins.

Komodo can be played competitively in both basic or strategic mode. In the former, wild cards are obtained randomly; in the latter, players can choose their wild cards. Actions permitted by a wild card include: releasing animals to free up their terrain; bartering or stealing terrain tiles; remodeling tiles already placed; and forcing an exchange of animals.

In the cooperative version of Komodo, all 32 animals must be housed and each player must place at least one animal during their turn. The game is played open-handed, and the wild cards hinder the players.

name.value: French Toast And Friends Fun Food Matching Game

item.description:
Can you help French Toast make the most pairs in this whimsical matching game for preschool-aged children? Featuring fun food and characters from the French Toast and Friends world!

Players match the most pairs by flipping over tile cards to win. If you don't make a match, tell everyone which turned tile card is your favorite, and why. Once all the tile cards have been matched, the player with the most matches wins.

Includes rules for the bonus Friends vs. Food Game. Players flip the cards over one at a time. Friends beats food! If you flip a friend tile card and you opponent flips a food, take both tile cards. Player with the most tile cards at the end wins!

Components:
50 Matching tile cards
2 Bonus sticker sheets

This is a spin and move game by J. W. Spear & Sons.
Each player has a piece that is used to make your way around the board. The inside box cover which has the rules for the game calls the game "A trip on the continent". By rolling dice players land on different spaces that cause either good or bad things to happen. Spot 13 says " after hurrying to the wrong station you lose a turn". Spot 25 says "sees the sights and lose a turn". #40 says "on the right road, advance to space 46". Many other things can happen while on your trip.

The object is to get to the finish line (#75) first.

The game was manufactured at the SPEAR WORKS in Bavaria
This is a Monopoly clone from Late from the Sky, a publisher that specializes in themed Monopoly games. All the deeds, spaces on the board and cards feature locations and landmarks from Austin.

item.description:
MEGA Bloks Memory Builder is a memory and matching game using 20 plastic maxi Mega Bloks in 4 different colours with animal pictures on them. These blocks are hidden randomly in a 'field' - a cardboard insert within the game box. Players can't see the animals, only the colored tops of the Mega Bloks. Each player takes one of four double-sided 'barn' cards showing a set of animals (four animals on each side, in four different colours). The cards have insert holes for a white Mega Bloks stand.

Players then take turns at pulling an animal block from the field, trying to be the first to find the four animals on their card. The first player to match all four animals on their barn card wins.

The game components are easy for small children to manage and the game is fun and challenging enough to hold interest. The double-sided cards allow some variety and replayability.

item.description:
The Commonwealth has decided to send the galaxy into martial law, sending probes out to all neighboring planets to keep an eye on any illegal contraband or fuel cells being used for the hyperspace lanes, a comfort only allowed by the Commonwealth and their Inquisitor Probes.

You have a destiny. You must travel from planet to planet from your home world, finding work to upgrade your ship or to obtain fuel cells, all while trying to find that one clue, just that one clue to your goal. The goal you yourself must accomplish. Be careful though for Inquisitor Probes run up and down the hyperspace lanes looking for folks like you. The Syndicate aren't that much fun either, placing embargo ships on planets and playing "pay the toll". You can do it though. I know you can.

After Objectives have been handed out, players take turns moving their Ship Tokens between the Planets, searching at each Planet first for their Objective’s Clue card and, once found, for their Objective’s Goal card. The first player to find their Goal card and return their Ship Token back to their Home Planet, residing there for one full rotation of players, wins the game! It sounds easy but you’ll want to collect Fuel Cells along the way, upgrade your Ship, take the occasional long route to avoid the Inquisitor Probes roaming the hyperspace lanes, complete jobs to earn rewards, ward off the Syndicate, and constantly be alert to the danger of other players attacking you. It was never going to be easy!

In the dice game Next!, players try to roll specific combinations of colors/symbols in order to claim target cards. The harder the target is to claim, the more points that card is worth.

To set up the game, shuffle the 45 target cards, then lay them out face up in stacks of 15 in the three card trays. On a turn, a player can roll the dice up to three times, setting aside any dice that she wants to keep after each of the first two rolls. If a player could claim a target card after the first or second roll – such as a card showing three-of-a-kind – but decides to roll again, she can no longer claim that card after a future roll. Once a player claims a card, her turn ends and the next player goes, rolling all six dice to start the turn.

If a player doesn't claim a card, however, the next player has the option of immediately claiming a card that matches the dice previously set aside or keeping those dice set aside and having only two rolls on his turn to try to claim a card.

Some cards have icons that allow whoever wins it to take a special action, such as a bonus turn or theft of a card from an opponent.

After a player has claimed a certain number of cards (4, 5 or 7 with four-to-six, three or two players), that player can decide to end the game. The game ends automatically once a player has claimed six, eight or ten cards (again, based on the number of players). Players then tally their points, and whoever has the high score wins!

item.description:
In Stratopolis, players want to build wide, while also building big.

Each player starts the game with twenty L-shaped tiles, each comprising three squares; one player has tiles showing all green squares, green and neutral squares, or two green squares and one red square, while the other player's tiles reverse red and green. Players shuffle and stack these tiles face down, revealing only the topmost tile.

To start the game, a two-square tile (one red, one green) is placed on the table. Players then take turns adding their topmost tile to the display. A tile can be placed (1) on the table with at least one edge adjacent to an edge in play or (2) on top of at least two tiles already in play. When placed on a higher level, each square of the tile must be supported, the tile must be level, and red and green squares cannot cover one another. (Every other color play – such as green on neutral or red on red – is legal.)

Once all tiles have been played, players count the scores of their zones, to find their best zone: number of squares in a contiguously connected area of their color times the height of the square in this area that is at the highest level. The player with the highest scoring zone wins.

Variant rules invite players to play with a hand of tiles that they refresh after each turn or to play with all tiles available at all time.

item.description: Patent Pending is card game for three to five players that simulates patent prosecution (i.e., the process by which one obtains a patent). On a player’s turn, the player plays one of their cards as a pending patent application that will be worth points if the application survives examination and issues as a patent. The remaining players act as the patent office by (a) playing a card from their hand as prior art against the pending patent application, (b) playing a card as an event to influence the play flow, or (c) passing. If the pending application survives the examination by the opposing players, then the patent application issues to the activate player. If the patent application is rejected, all the cards played are discarded. At the end of the game, the player with the most points wins.

Colorpop seems like a video game brought to the board game world, complete with a cool gadget to mimic the work done by our digital overlords.

The game board consists of an inclined plastic holder that holds ten racks, with each rack holding ten colored tokens. Tokens come in five player colors (19 each) and the white Jokers (5). To set up the game, slide the tokens into the racks, then place the racks in the holder so that no more than color has more than five tokens orthogonally connected. Each player then receives a token that reveals her color for the game, a token that she keeps hidden from other players.

On a turn, a player chooses a group of two or more orthogonally connected tokens and pushes on these tokens so that they fall through the racks and down the holder. (A player can choose to make a joker any color, so she can include or exclude a joker as she wishes during her turn.) Any tokens that were above these will slide down inside the racks. The player keeps all the tokens removed.

Players take turns removing tokens until either a player is eliminated from the game or no groups of two or more tokens remain. At this point, the game ends and players reveal their secret colors. Whoever has the fewest tokens of her color on the board wins! If two or more players are tied, they compare the tokens they collected during the game; whoever collected fewer of his or her own color wins.

item.description:
"La bola de fuego" (The Fireball) it's a simple roll-and-move game in wich the players, taking the role of explorers, must enter a volcanic island and race against each other to catch some diamonds, avoiding the dangers that lurk within the place (Slippery caves, swaying bridges, crocodiles, octopuses and, of course, fireballs), and trying to escape first.

A quite lackluster game, trying to capitalize on the success of the more well-known Fireball Island (even directly stealing its front box artwork), made by knock-off specialist Falomir Juegos.

Rise of Rebels is a 2 player territory control wargame. Players deploy units, research tech and battle for control cities in an effort to achieve their secret objectives. Each round players choose three action cards which constrains the actions they may take during the round.

When a player has acquired the requisite number of Victory Points by claiming successfully completed objective cards they win.

Included with the game is the Rise of Rebels: Legacy variant. The Legacy variant takes two players through a campaign that details the story of the rival factions represented in the game (the rival Rebel organizations) as they battle for control of the space station. This variant involves making permanent modifications to the game bard and faction components based on the outcome of each battle.

Welcome to the wild, weird world of FANTASTIQA!

Fantastiqa is a deck-building board game set in a fantastical landscape of dark forests, mist-shrouded highlands, and frozen wastes. As you and your foes journey around the board, you will subdue strange creatures and fulfill fabulous quests.

Each creature you encounter has both an ability and a vulnerability. By playing card symbols to which a creature is vulnerable, you can subdue it and recruit it as an ally. Each creature you defeat is added to your expanding deck of cards, making its special ability into an ability of your own! A defeated Enchantress will wield her beguiling charms to help you overcome wandering Knights. Knights in turn subdue Dragons, adding their fiery breath to your cause. By combining the powers of different creatures you can fulfill curious quests, for example:


 Send forth your Rabbits of Unusual Size to Nibble Through the Violin Strings of the Violent Vampire Volnar!
 Deploy a party of web-slinging Spiders to String a Bridge Across the Chasm of Chaos!
 Send your Dragons and Vampire Bats together on a mission to Ignite the Whisker-Wick'd Candle Guarded by the Ice Cats of Kituviel!


Some of the creatures you encounter carry precious gems, which you can spend to purchase powerful artifacts or to summon mythical beasts to your aid. You begin with a handful of household items, but you will grow in power as you adventure and gather allies! By completing quests you score victory points and claim other special rewards. The board changes every time you play, so prepare for a new, exciting adventure each time you enter the world of Fantastiqa!

Fantastiqa is easy to learn but challenging to master – a game for families and gamers alike. Additional simplified rules are included for beginners and children.

The components are lavishly illustrated with fine art by Caspar David Friedrich, Vincent van Gogh, Claude Monet, Arthur Rackham, John William Waterhouse, John Bauer, Edward Burne-Jones, Francisco Goya, and others.

item.description:
A tiny free promotional demonstration version of real-time pattern recognition game Spot it!.

In standard Dobble, there are 55 cards, each with 8 symbols. In this free demo version, there are 16 cards (of smaller size), each with 6 symbols (from a subset of the full version's set of symbols). As in standard Dobble, each pair of cards has exactly 1 symbol in common, which is the basis of the simple real-time pattern recognition games included.

item.description:
Ísland-opoly is a licenced Monopoly clone which theme is unsurprisingly Iceland. The properties are famous landmarks, tourist attractions, building and so on.

From the publisher:
How do we make a board game about the most fun country in the world?
It's impossible to put all the great places of Iceland in one board game so we have chosen fun places and landmarks all over the country. We start in the Hvalfjörður and travel all around the country that keeps surprising us with natural disasters and unexpected happenings.

How do you play Ísland-opoly?
You can buy famous places or landmarks all around the country, up the rent by buying houses and upgrade them to hotels. Sounds easy? We'll figure it out! Traffic jam, radar guns and the police can make it harder for us, but that's just more fun!

You pick a fun pawn and go to the starting place, perhaps you'll become the richest person in Iceland... or just stuck in a traffic jam because of the ash cloud!

Get ready for the game! This is our country... and it's your turn!

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
Pay Dirt is an engine-building, worker placement game set in frigid Alaska for 2-5 players. Players are competing to manage and grow their entire mining outfit while acquiring the most gold before the ground is too frozen to dig. The Alaskan countryside is an inhospitable environment, so players will face hardships that affect their entire outfit – not to mention the ever-dropping temperature that will shut down their operation.

In Pay Dirt players start with a small basic crew, an unimpressive claim, mediocre equipment and just a little bit of cash to make a go in one of the toughest competitions this side of the globe. Gold mining isn’t cheap and players will have to sell their gold throughout the game to keep the equipment running and their workers happy. Through clever use of their equipment and workers, players can make their mining outfits more efficient and dialed in to their preference of play. Will you recruit heavily and stack your camp with workers or will you keep your eyes on better and more efficient equipment? Will you have what it takes to hit to strike it rich and hit pay dirt?

link.value: Pay Dirt: The Last Frontier Mini Expansion

item.description:
In Kolory, each player is trying to create as large a territory as possible through clever card play.

To set up the game, one card showing four white quadrants is placed on the table while each player holds ten cards, with each card having four quadrants of a particular color. On a turn, a player adds a card to the playing area, laying it adjacent to other cards already in play or covering one or more cards – but only one quadrant can be covered on each card.

Once all the cards have been played, the player with the largest area of orthogonally-connected quadrants scores one point per quadrant. The player with the most points after a certain number of rounds wins.

item.description:
Treasure-Hunters

On this occasion I propose to players searching for sunken treasure, in what once were large ships at some point in history, and for some reason or another, suffered from the punishment of the sea, until the scourge of pirates, buccaneers and privateers but today, we rescued who were sleeping sleep for centuries.

To move around the board, we will have several boats that will be used to navigate until you get to the coordinates indicated and initiate searches galleons, wrecks, ships and all kinds of boats that sailed these waters for centuries.

If we can find the part, the spoils can be of incalculable amount and report if found some interesting benefits.

In terms of mechanical and manufacturing included two forms of the game printed on one side is the most expensive and luxurious yet what material is concerned, and the other which I find very interesting and can serve to make the game a minimum cost.

name.value: The Human Race: A matter of life and death

item.description:
The Human Race is a game for people of all ages. As you play, you will see that each move is like life itself, with rules that allow for freedom of choice and ensuing consequences. Here you will witness the gravity of your own judgement and values, as well as that of others. What will be sacrificed to win the Human Race?

Unlike other games that endorse a win-at-any-cost moral, The Human Race demonstrates that employing such a moral is possible, but not likely to win the game. Points, intelligence, cunning or luck may win the game, but if you play with heart and conscience you will never lose.

Bitterness over loss has no role in The Human Race. For if you lose, it is totally your own doing. The freedom of choice is yours. Whether you play to teach your children or learn about yourself, The Human Race gives you hours of fun.

The rules are simple. The play, intricate. Downright soul-searching. The Human Race.

Playing the Game: First player rolls the white die and moves the number of squares indicated by the die moving in a clockwise direction. If a player lands on a square which points are indicated those points are added if it is a blue square (good)
and deducted from the score if it is a red square (evil). After the player has moved, they draw a blue card or red card determined by their final location, either adding (good) or deducting (evil) points from their score or following the instructions on the card.

Rolling the Life Dice: After following the instructions on the card the player rolls the three black "Life Dice". If all three dice show the same number then the player dies. If on a red square or has negative points the player is out of the game. If a player dies while having positive points and on a blue square, then even though the player is out, they still may win the game -- that is if all the other players do not reach the Final Resting Place with positive points or if the others die with fewer good points.

Final Resting Place: The game is won by the player to reach the Final Resting Place. If no player reaches the Final Resting Place, then the player who dies with the most good points is the winner.

Cia: Cyber Ops is a collectible card game played between two or more players each of whom are computer programmers trying to program their three Computers before their opponents. Using cards like Operations, Programs, Viruses, Firewalls, and Special Agents each player tries to program their Computers, thwart their opponent’s attempts to do the same and protect against devastating and underhanded attacks.

CIA: Cyber Ops is marketed primarily towards Christian home school students in Michigan as a way of providing an alternative to Magic: The Gathering, while encouraging academic development in math skills.

The game can be purchased in main sets and boosters. The game is currently in it's fourth series of main sets.

From the game description:

Take to the Skies!

Fly a patrol over the trenches and tangle with enemy planes in this set collection card game! Conserve your ammo as you jockey for position, attempting to line up the perfect shot. Choose from 24 different historic aircraft, each with different performance attributes which suffer as the plane takes damage. You may wind up an ace, or go down in flames!


 


Dogfight is a World War I aerial combat flavored set collection card game in which players strive to collect then play sets of cards to line up a chance to damage their opponents.

The game features set collection, card drafting, and variable player powers.

Throughout the game, players manage their altitude and speed while trying to collect the cards necessary to attack each other.

Damage is recorded, not as hit points, but as degradation to the plane's unique performance attributes. Such damage could eventually cause the plane to be forced down, start on fire, go into an uncontrolled spin, or break up in midair. It is also possible to hit the opposing pilot with a machine gun bullet, killing him instantly.

It's dangerous up there, and Dogfight is not for the faint of heart!

In the card game Cowtown, you want to move cows into the right herds so that you can score points and empty your hand.

At the start of each round, each player receives a hand of six cards, then four more cards are placed face-up on the table; the deck includes cards in four colors, numbered 1-10 twice, along with two "Cowtown" cards of each color. Cowtown cards are always played on the table immediately in order to give the little dogies a place to settle.

On a turn, you play a card from your hand onto a stack on the table. The card you play must be one higher than the top card on a stack. (Cowtown cards are effectively numbered 0.) If you can play multiple cards in numerical order – a Horn-to-Tail Sequence – you can do so; in addition (or alternatively) you can play multiple cards with the same number – a Stampede – onto different stacks when those stacks have the same lower number. Playing a three-card Horn-to-Tail Sequence or a Stampede is worth 1 "scorecow".

Whenever you play a card of matching color onto a stack, you're safe, but if you play at least one card of a different color – a bullish play – then you must draw and discard the top card of the deck. If that card shows a red bull's eye, then you've been kicked and must draw a card. Lay a 10 on a stack and you close that barn, getting to take another turn or pass one of your cards to another player.

The round ends as soon as one player is out of cards or the deck runs out. The player with the fewest cards earns 4 scorecows, the player with the next fewest 2 scorecows, and everyone other than the player with the most cards earns 1 scorecow. After four rounds, whoever holds the most scorecows wins!

item.description:
Ice Age is a Sudoku of people interaction and strategy.

Ice Age is a 30 minute one to four player Sudoku game. The goal of the game is to complete a 4x5 Sudoku puzzle or a 5x5 puzzle in a single player game. In each round, players roll four dice simultaneously, and begin with the starting player, each player takes one action per turn to place, remove, or replace a number base on the number rolled. Player may also use other's dice, except number 6, the joker. When all dice are used or players passed, a round ends.

When a row of 1 to 5 is completed, player receives victor point based on the time of completion. When a player finishes the puzzle or 7th round ends, game ends, and the player with highest score wins the game.

Game description from the publisher:

Trap the Triceratops! Apprehend the Apatosaurus! Race to capture sets of matching dinosaurs in the ferociously fun card game Super Tooth. The bigger the set, the bigger your reward — but don't bite off more than you can chew, or you may fall prey to a Velociraptor, a volcano, or even the dreaded T. Rex! Collect the most sets and you'll go down in prehistory!

item.description:
An abstract strategy game for 2 players. It is played using a wooden board, marked into 64 squares, and 12 'ancient' looking coins, 6 silver and 6 gold. Five of each set of coins show a Wheel on one side and a Foot on the other, and the sixth coin has a Flag on both sides. There is also a small metal die.

Each player begins the game with his 6 pieces positioned on opposite corners of the board. On the throw of the die a player may move up to 3 pieces corresponding to the number shown. A Flag, a Wheel and a Foot move differently on the board. If a Foot stops on the centre square it is turned over to become a Wheel. Specific movement rules come into play when a confrontation occurs. For example, a Foot piece must be removed from the game if it is confronted by two opposing Foot pieces.

The game may be won in 3 ways:
a) by surrounding your opponent's Flag with any 3 pieces;
b) by removing all of your opponent's pieces from the game; or
c) by capturing your opponent's undefended Flag with your Foot.

The components are good quality - 'ancient' playing pieces, a burgundy and gold wooden board, a velvet draw-string bag for the coins.

Designed and produced in Australia. This is obviously a quality, small production but unfortunately the rules aren't available anywhere on the internet and the publisher's website no longer exists.

Idiot Knowledge is not a traditional quiz game with a boring and slow questions. This is the game instead of all that is not learned about in school ...

Do you know how many percent better boys perform as they train in the gym in front of the girls? Is it possible to tattoo on the tongue? or Why Mona Lisa has no eyebrows?

Over 400 hilarious crazy, bizarre and totally meaningless, but still super interesting and entertaining questions, that's as fun to be able to answer as to hear the answer! Idiot Knowledge is the perfect game for anyone who loves knowledge mixed with meaningless nonsense and lots of humor!

Gameplay is similar to many other trivia games. Roll the dice, move Your pawn, draw a card.

name.value: Ego: The Adult Game of Communication

item.description:
The fun filled thought provoking discussion generated between players demonstrates the qualities of being unique and being human. To express your opinion of a subject's qualities (player being evaluated), each analyst (all remaining players) must dial their "opinionators" to display a most/least or yes/no answer. Characteristics shown on Ego cards require your opinion of what the player is most and least like. When a statement is read from an Alter Ego card, your yes or no opinion is required of what you think the subject will say. There are no intrinsically right or wrong answers, but answering gives everyone a chance to express their opinions.

Playing The Game: To select the first subject, an Ego card is drawn by each player. The player whose characteristics begin with the letter nearest the beginning of the alphabet becomes the first subject. The subject then collects all Ego cards drawn and places them face up in the Tripper so that each space contains at least one card. All remaining players and the subject then express their opinions of the subject by dialing their opinionators to mach the most/least color combination under the Ego cards in the tripper.

Example: The three Ego cards displayed read generous, expressive and shy. If a player perceives the subject as being more expressive than shy or generous then the player would dial their opinionator to reveal the word most in the color that matches the color under the expressive ego card in the tripper. If the player perceives the subject as being less shy than generous then the player would dial their opinionator to reveal the word least in the color matching the "shy" ego card under the tripper making sure that the Most color already is revealed at the same time. When all players are ready they turn over their opinionators to reveal their opinions.

How to Score: The subject moves forward one square for each analyst opinion that matches his, plus one of his own. Players whose opinions do not match any other player move back one square. Players cannot move further back than the beginner square. Player whose opinions match one or more players remain where they are and are not penalized even if they do not match the subject's opinion. After scoring the player on the subject's left becomes the next subject and the next session is played.

Winning the Game: Play continues with a new subject being evaluated after each session is complete. The player who reaches the winners circle first is the winner.

From the box:

¿Aquatic animals beginning with D or I? Being faster than the rest of the family, Kevin hits the beep and activates the sound & light referee. Then he have 3 seconds to give his answer: "Dolphin!" He wins! Kevin discards a card and the game continues

It's easy!. Simply find a word beginning with a particular letter on one of the 66 entertaining topics. Only your own quick thinking and coolness will allow you the victory. To increase the variety and interest of the game, we propose two levels: 33 cards with easy and distracting issues to Play with the children and most difficult 33 tokens for the adults.

name.value: Glory of the Three Kingdoms: Guandu Core Set

item.description:
Glory of the Three Kingdoms is a living deck-building game (LDBG) in which each player takes a role leading an allegiance in the Three Kingdoms period and battles for total victory or for victory points.

As in most deck-building games, player acquire additional cards to add to their decks. In GOTK, player may acquire cards depicting heroes, military, strategy, items, etc., and some cards provide victory points for endgame scoring. Unlike other games of this type, GOTK has a battle phase during which each player secretly deploys military cards (foot soldiers, pikemen, calvary and archers) and battles for Glory. The victor takes a glory token from the defeated player and a free card in the neutral zone. The victor may also capture and recruit the defeated general – or have him beheaded.

When two out of four card decks are depleted, the game ends and the player with the most victory points wins. However, if one allegiance acquired six or more Tiger Tally or all of opponent's glory tokens, the game ends immediately and the allegiance wins.

The first battle theme of GOTK is Guandu, the first major battle in the Three Kingdoms period. The Guandu Core Set, a two-player game, comes with Cao Cao and Yuan Shao allegiances. Lu Bu and Liu Bei allegiances will be available in a future three- and four-player expansion.

item.description: This is a very simple game for kids 4 to 8. You simply spin the spinner and move your marble from the start line to the finish. If your spin causes you to land on another players marble you simply stop one space short of where your opponents marble is.

A game of mimic in which the players, playing in couples, must discern which movie his partner is representing. As they guess them correctly (or fail in doing so), they advance (or move back) their tokens, 'till someone reach the "best director" square to win the Oscar and the game. After that, all the players can vote who's been the best actor and award him other little Oscar.

Octopunk is a tile placement exploration game set in the near future, transgenic octopi have been tasked with building a human habitat on Europa's deep ocean floor. Players pick one of five different uplifted octopi and search 36 exploration tiles looking for the resources to build the dome while dodging the very dangerous dragon jellyfish. the humans will arrive in only four years and if the mission is not complete everyone loses. The Game consists of twenty five eight sided Ocean Floor zones in the spaces between the octagonal zones square exploration tiles are placed face down, they may contain either resources or hazards for the players to discover.
 If the players have completed building the human habitat and surrounded it with four defense turrets (before the humans arrive) then points are scored by resources collected, structures built, and hazards defeated.

name.value: Dogs of War: Legends of the Crushed Planes

item.description:
Dogs of War is a wargame using 22mm miniatures to form together into squads that take to the battlefield and wage war on each other. The game has a rich history and setting with unique races and models. During each round of play, a player can move his or her squads, strike and shoot at enemy squads and even cast magic designed to help you and hinder allies. Various scenarios exist in the game that will define goals for the game, time limits and other details. There is even, in development, a campaign set of rules that will be designed directly into the core set of rules. Each race has it's own set of special rules and squad lists with attributed points values to make the game a "fair fight."

Play as one of several races for dominion and survival in the crushed planes. Play as the Ng'Awuthii, otherwise known as the Ng to foreign races, an advanced race of humanoids who possess technology far surpassing the technology of all other races combined. Or play as the talwart Tuskers, tribes of wise and savage nobility who use their heavy weaponry, tough skin and rending tusks to demolish their foes. Play as these, or several other races including the beautiful Eduran people who wield powerful magic and fight with inhuman grace, or the infamous Nameless, insect kin who travel above-ground in a pupal state which appear kin to dwarves of mythology or even the Kingdoms of Man.

This is a Monopoly clone from Late from the Sky, a publisher that specializes in themed Monopoly games. All the deeds, spaces on the board and cards feature locations and landmarks from Kansas City.

Players roll dice to determine how far they move. Landing on a space gives the player the option of buying the property. When a player collects all the properties in one color group, the properties can be improved by first building skylines, and then upgrading to keys to the city. When players land on a space owned by another player they must pay rent. Rent is determined by the location of the property and the number of improvements on the space. Some spaces instruct a player to draw a card which can be beneficial or harmful to the player. Players must avoid going bankrupt to stay in the game. The winner is the last player left in the game.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
The game
The aim of the game is to become rich. To do that, as merchant, the player should pay attention in selling, to do intelligent loans of money and wise investments.
The player represents a young merchant which should demonstrate all his ability to become the richest merchant of Venice.

How to play
The game is dividet into four turns. Each turn is divided into four round.
The first round concerns the travel organization in Venice, after the auction sale of the rights to be in command of each "muda". The players then must play to load the ships.
The second round concerns the selling of the goods that they are loaded. The goods must be sell in the same order as they were loaded.
In the third round the player can buy products in Oltremare and in the final step return to Venice. Here the players can sell their products or store them in their warehouses. The aim to store goods is to load them next turn, to sell them in another destination more profitable.

I'm looking for interested publishers for printing

item.description:
"Off with his Head!" is a part of the "Tudor - Life in Times of Treason & Treachery" history kit which includes:
- History book
- Board game and dice
- Stickers
- Mini felt pens
- Colouring activity
- Press-out ship

Is it your unlucky day? Are you on the way to the block on Tower Green? Or will you be the one to get a Royal Pardon? Take it in turns to roll one dice, and obey the instructions on the board. When you get towards the end, you must roll the exact number to finish on 100. So if, for example, you're on square 97 and throw a 5, you go forward 3 spaces to 100, then 2 back and land on 98. When you throw the exact number, you've finished. The last (!) person to reach square 100 gets the Royal Pardon and wins!

Colonial Space Wars (CSW) is a tactical game based on a futuristic universe of science fiction that recreates battles between two or more armies. Each army is composed of square game pieces measuring 1.2 x 1.2 inches which represent their units.

During the game, pieces move across a rectangular board divided into squares arranged in rows and columns. In a game of CSW, each player has a number of units in his army which is set depending on the faction they are playing. We call this set of units a “Combat Sword. Two basic Combat Swords (Union of Terra and Alpha Centauri Brotherhood) are available for an introductory game of CSW.

Game pieces represent the units, troops, and vehicles of a fighting force. The pieces have two sides, Front (Illustration and Health arrow) and Back (Name, Attributes and Skills). A player has some pieces with the skill Leader (X). While these pieces are on the board, they grant X command points at the beginning of each turn. Each side alternates turns, making one or more moves depending on the number of Command points available.

Each unit requires a number of command points to be used that turn; this is referred to as “Activating ” the unit. When all command points are spent, the opponent’s turn begins. Each unit, upon being activated, can move and act in any order. The possible actions are “Move”, “Embark/disembark”, “Attack” and “Use active skills”. A typical game is a Sudden Death match, where the winner is the player that eliminates the ir opponent’s ability to activate units.

item.description:
The boss just fired the manager of his most prestigious strip club and is now looking for a new manager.

In Lap Dance, players take the role of entertainment assistants at that strip club. Their job is to take care of valued customers and see to their needs. Those wealthy customers will be asking for dancers, drinks and luxury services and will be paying good money to the assistant that fulfills their wishes. The player who will generate the most money by satisfying customer demands will become the new manager.

item.description: A golf boardgame containing 9 courses. The courses are stylistic rather than realistic in their portrayal, containing colored fields and numbered circles. The players use two ordinary six sided dice and move their markers to circles with numbers that are the same as the sum of their throw. The distribution of the numbered circles is made so that bad shots are less likely to occur (ie. bunker, ruff etc.) than shots to fairway. Putting is made using a special dice. Every hole has a small rule set that makes unusual events possible, such as hole in one etc.

This age of art and capitalism has created a need for a new occupation - The Gallerist.

Combining the elements of an Art dealer, museum curator, and Artists’ manager, you are about to take on that job! You will promote and nurture Artists; buy, display, and sell their Art; and build and exert your international reputation. As a result, you will achieve the respect needed to draw visitors to your Gallery from all over the world.

There's a lot of work to be done, but don't worry, you can hire assistants to help you achieve your goals. Build your fortune by running the most lucrative Gallery and secure your reputation as a world-class Gallerist!

Maximize your money and thus win the game by: 

 having visitors in your gallery; 
 exhibiting and selling works of art;
 investing in artists’ promotion to increase art value;
 achieving trends and reputation as well as curator and dealer goals.

item.description: From the rules: This is a most interesting and instructive game. As many children can play as there are individual playing cards. Give each player a card and place all the filler pieces in the center of the table face down. The object of the game is to complete cards correctly. Players draw from the face down fillers and try to complete a figure. If he/she does so the player draws another filler card and tries to add it properly. He continues to pick fillers until he draws a filler card that does not belong on his card. When that happens he/she returns the filler card face down into the center. After having mixed it with the rest of the remaining filler cards play continues in turn until someone completes their card and wins the game,

Game has 105 cards, each bearing a picture of some object connected with the Bible or Bible times and in most cases one or more Bible references. Shuffle the cards and deal 10 cards to each player. Each player tries to make books. Three cards of the same class of subjets make up a book. These completed books are placed aside till the end of the game when they are counted. Whoever has the most books wins.

Each player calls any player he wishes and asks for a card from any series - (Animals, Trees etc.) If successful then the player may continue asking for other cards from any player he wants until he asks for a card from a player and that player does not have one that he asked for, at which time the active player draws 3 cards from the deck and play passes to the next player to his left.

Game #4012

Contents:
104 cards (4 sets of 26 cards)
rules

Includes rules for three separate games.

Game #1: The "Grab it quick" game
The Knock Knock cards are shuffled and placed in a draw pile, while the Who's There cards are placed face up on the table. A player says "Knock Knock", the other players respond, "Who's there?" and then all players race to find the correct card from those face up on the table. The person who grabs it first keeps both cards, and the person with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

Game #2: Advanced grab it
Same as Game #1, except the Who's There cards are placed face down, adding a memory element.

Game #3: The "Remember Where" game
Instead of a draw pile, each player is dealt 4 Knock Knock cards, and on their turn must match a Knock Knock card to the Who's There cards which are face down on the table. If a player makes a match, they keep the cards and get a second turn. The player with the most cards at the end of the game wins.

Game consist of 4 pieces representing fire department apparatus and a spining dial. The movment of the various pieces of apparatur to the location of the fire is beset with many obstacles such as traffic jams, open drawbridges over which they must pass, railroad crossing with gates down, detours, engine and tire troubles and collisions which must be overcome. The oject of the game is to see which player best moves his piece of apparatus to the location of the fire, go into action, limber up his piece, put out the fire and then return to his fire house returning to their station by exact count on the spinner,

Mix between Trivia game and Top Trumps

The 32 trump cards are mixed. Each player receives 16 cards in front of them. The target goal is set in the middle of the table. 
The first player draws his top card and choose one of the four category, reads it and its value. The enemy reads value of same category. The higher value wins. The losing player ask the question from the card. Winner of the duel can answer the question and wins if he answer correctly. Otherwise he loses to opponent.
Some cards are with word "target goal", then the duel winner may shoot the goal.
After 16 duels the player who now has fewer cards takes "the end of the game" card and puts it behind his stack of cards. 
Duels continues until this card.
The winner is the player who has more trump cards in his hand.

BATTLE THIS! is the ultimate two players (Ages 12 to Adult) strategic board game for those who are looking for a challenge. The game consists of two military forces; Green and Brown. Each force has a total of 16 playing pieces: 8 Soldiers, 4 Tanks and 4 Fighter Planes. Each playing pieces move and capture a certain way and each playing pieces are worth a certain amount of points. The objective of the game is to try to outwit your opponent; eliminate all of his / her playing pieces while trying to score as many points as you can.

The Game
Fleets at War! is a tactical wargame played on the floor or a large table with cardboard counters representing starships, fighters, and other space craft, set in the same universe as the Imperium Chronicles Role Playing Game.
 The wargame consists of three major factions: the Imperium, the Magna Supremacy, and the Pirate Clans.

The IMP System
Fleets at War! uses the IMP System that reduces the number of die rolls necessary during play. All other calculations are done by referencing a chart of two opposing attributes (ex. Damage vs. Armor) to find a result. The goal of this system is to speed up play and allow for large-scale battles.

Game Scale
Each counter in the game represents a single starship or a flight of four to five fighters. An inch equals approximately 0.2 miles, or a mile equals 5 inches. Each game turn equals roughly 2 to 3 minutes.

Stat Cards
Each class of ship (i.e.: heavy cruiser, destroyer, frigate, etc.) has a one- or two-sided card listing all the stats for that class, including its offensive and defensive capabilities.

link.value: Imperium Chronicles: Fleets at War – Claws of Chaos

item.description:
The game consists of two phases. In the first phase, a players assemble a large (100 cm x 70 cm) jigsaw puzzle map of Italy. In the second phase, players roll numbered and colored dice to place their tokens on cities and to place the special tiles representing the special landmarks of the regional capitals.

Players seek to place all of their tokens on cities and to place all of the regional capitals from their hands on to the board. The numbered die indicates the quantity of tokens that may be placed, while the colored die indicates who may play tokens or place a regional capital tile.

The first player to place all of her tokens and regional capital tiles wins the game.

item.description:
Players first assemble the large jigsaw puzzle game board then roll and move to take a tour of Italy.

Each turn, players roll a die and advance along a marked route from the starting point at Rome. Landing on a red spot ends the turn; landing on a green spot allows the player to advance two extra cities; landing on a yellow spot causes a player to go back one city.

The winner is the first player to complete the entire tour route and return to Rome by exact die roll.

item.description:
Forest opoly is a version of Monopoly published by Late for the Sky, a company that specializes in Monopoly clones. All the spaces, deeds, and cards have facts about wild animals on them.

Players roll dice to determine how far they move. Landing on a space gives the player the option of buying the property. When a player collects all the properties in one color group, the properties can be improved by building. When players land on a space owned by another player they must pay rent. Rent is determined by the location of the property and the number of improvements on the space. Some spaces instruct a player to draw a card which can be beneficial or harmful to the player. Players must avoid going bankrupt to stay in the game. The winner is the last player left in the game.

link.value: Late for the Sky Production Company

item.description:
It is a new card game that 2 or more people compete to spell most number of words using the most number of cards. It is unique that anyone can capture ('Bite') others' words by creating new ones from the spelled ones at any time, which makes the game fast pace and fun.

The person who has the most vocabulary may not necessarily win because smart use of special cards can turn the tide very quickly.

name.value: Battle of Kawagoe: Hojo Ujiyasu's gamble
河越合戦 北条氏康の賭け

item.description:
Operational level wargame of the Kawagoe battle during the Warring States Period (æˆ¦å›½æ™‚ä»£ Sengoku jidai) in Japan. The Kawagoe battle is one of three major surprise attack in Japanese History.

Players control either Hojo clan or Allied force of Uesugi clan and Ashikaga Shogunate. Each player manage command allocation, movement and combat. Both force has different characteristics. Hojo clan has small size but trained powerfull units. They also has special activation chit for Hojo Tsunasige. He was commander of Kawagoe castle and made he made effective sortie in this battle. Allied force has large units more than Hojo clan but their command control was inefficient because their armies was patchwork from many clans.

Winner determined by special sudden-death condition or victory point. Victory point earn by elimination of opponent units and condition of Kawagoe Castle.
